Thus, while Humanity can last forever, each single human, cannot.

I disagree with the sentiment that "forgery = plagiarism." Plagiarism is the copying of very specific information, but art is conceptual. In a world where the distance between a sentence and my eyeball can be called somebody else's sculpture with a straight face, I don't think it's fair to say that a forgery is any less a piece of distinctive art than the work of art being copied. Maybe the act of forging is the forger's haiku? And that works, because they count the rate of cloud formation in the skies over a particular Argentinian city when determining their count of syllables. You can't (IMO) "copy" an experience which is so completely subjective that even suggesting it ought to have some connection with reality is an act which some people find offensive.

It’s interesting - I wrote a piece like this a while ago, but I diverged in several respects but I will mention just the first.
There’s no ‘aura’ around an original artwork - that’s silly. We value the original simply because it is a special type of creation, as distinct from the copies made of it. That is, the forgers all lacked the IDEA of doing the piece. We can value that intangible even though there may be literally no difference between the original and its copy. There’s no aura other than our KNOWING that the original artist was inspired to create his work from nothing but their mind.

I explored some different aspects of the DNA replication discussion but Michael’s through line is fine as it stands.

At 1:03 you say what's stored on the drive (in the server or wherever) is just instructions for making the video? How is that true, that doesn't even make sense.. We're not talking about executable files here (which is instructions / opcodes, and data for those instructions to manipulate or possibly just instructions). Media files obviously contain information for displaying the text or picture or whatever, that's the point of saving the file.. Then when you choose to access the file from the hard drive again, the processor transfers it to the video card so it (the video card) can do the work.

Look at a simple text file for example (same concept as a video, it's still a file with information to display on the screen). The hard drive contains the 8 bit ASCII patterns for every character in the text file. Say you create a text file and save it to the hard drive and it's 100 characters long. Those 100 characters (meaning the 8 bit ASCII patterns) are now stored at a contiguous (or fragmented) location on the hard drive, 100 bytes. Say you request to see that file. Now the processor runs a program that transfers that file (100 bytes) into the video card memory so it can be converted to output on the screen for us to view.

Anyway, my point is, the hard drive does store information about the files, even though they aren't pictures as we see them (obviously) but instead as the language the computer "understands" (higher voltage levels being 1s, and lower being 0s). For example, that 8 bit ascii pattern stored on the hard drive doesn't look like an 'A' to us, but it's whats needed for the computer to in effect show the text file after triggering the right things. Enlighten me if I'm wrong

I think "forgeries" is the wrong word. "Forgery" implies deception as to the origins of something, where most things that aren't artistic in nature are either duplicated from or inspired by something else rather than forgeries of whatever original. I would say that living things are actually extensions of the original work rather than forgeries, given that if you think of a common ancestor as having any kind of purpose it would be to create more living things. Also, the concept of being "related" breaks down when you get out of things that actually reproduce.

Hello there! Vsauce? Fifty generations? I thought the people that wandered out of Africa first, aka the original Europeans and Asians, bred with Neanderthals 40,000 - 10,000 BC. Original Africans didn't, and they still don't share this piece of DNA. Thus, Africans and Indo-Europeans can't have bred with each other for at least 42,000 - 12,000 years. A generation typically lasts maybe 18 - 30 years. That leaves me with up to 2,000 generations between Africans and Indo-Europeans.
  You maybe forgot about Epigenetics too. Genes above DNA that is. Still, humans share a lot of DNA and I don't want to sound like I am some kind of racist. Race is just a word without much scientific meaning. Jews, especially, are not a race. They've just been for about 6,000 years in comparison. I don't think Caucasians nor Asians came to be over night, still.

PS - I precisely read a page on modern science that put the extinction of the Neanderthals to 40,000 - 39,000 years ago, which means there is at least more difference between human races than races of dogs, even though they have much shorter generations. Call me a racist (even though I don't discriminate other races), but I don't think it would be especially great if humanity lost this ancient heritage to some modern pop culture. Or maybe I misunderstand genetics on some fundamental level. (I don't know what a genome is).

Contained on a file system being hosted in one of Google's massive server cluster.
It is comprised of a series of images being played by the web player at a certain speed. The web player is really just displaying the images contained at rapid speeds, and embeds itself into the web page for efficiency.

Now that there are better tools available to accomplish this, Flash is being phased out in favor of HTML5 (Hyper Text Markup Language).

It's kind of simple, really. It's like a gif, but with better compression, a better storage method, and faster due to a dedicated player.

dude dude DUUUDE .. can't even begin to tell you how wrong you are about the part where you said that someone downloaded and uploaded same video many times and it corrupted.

Video did not corrupt because of downloading and uploading, video corrupt because of YOUTUBE.
Every time you upload a video, youtube re-renders it, no matter what format the file is. So when you download the video, you won't get the same video that you have in your pc, it will be completely different (size and quality). So doing it over and over .. everyone knows that re-rendering same video with same settings will make quality go worse with every render.

I think that now youtube allows owner of account to download the RAW original video file, but at the time this guy made a video it was not possible, so he always got the re-rendered version.

That .01% of DNA is still a lot of DNA. It doesn't sound like much, but there are trillions of bits of data in one single chromosome (not even a pair of them, a single one) of DNA, so .01% is still a lot of data. We just think of it by comparison, so 99.9% makes .01% sound like next to nothing. And in theory, the same elementary particles that made us when we were born are still inside of us (or at least most of them are) because even though the atoms are being destroyed and created, the particles are simply being rearranged (the quarks from two neutrons can go to make a proton).

People in the "western" world have blonde hairs, blue or green eyes and so on....

There are people I honestly despise. They lack morals, character, and honesty. They defile the present and destroy the future. In case you can't tell, I'm talking about Michael here. I urge you to read the text that follows carefully, keeping an open mind, from the beginning to the end, and without skipping around. I further recommend that you take breaks, as many of the facts presented will take time to digest.

Michael's apologists doubtlessly don't want us to prevent the “invisible hand” of loosely regulated markets from becoming an “invisible fist” that lets Michael effortlessly pound his castigators into oblivion. That'd be too much of a threat to paternalism, presenteeism, and all of the other deluded things they worship. Clearly, they prefer carrying our once-proud nation deeper into savagery and depravity. Before explaining why primitive antagonists cause insurmountable trouble for us, I must first point out that the emperor has no clothes on. As a matter of fact, he has gotten carried away with acquiring public acceptance of his boisterous activities. It's pretty clear from this lack of restraint that he would abrogate some of our most fundamental freedoms, all at the drop of a hat. It's therefore imperative that we invigorate the effort to reach solutions by increasing the scope of the inquiry rather than by narrowing or abandoning it, as doing so will let Michael know that he is extraordinarily brazen. We've all known that for a long time. However, Michael's willingness to make serious dialogue difficult or impossible sets a new world record for brazenness.

As fickle as Michael's zingers are, when Michael stated that squalid clowns aren't ever sneaky, I concluded that he was totally impractical. Now that he claims that his flock consists entirely of lovable, cuddly people who would never dream of consigning our traditional values to the rubbish heap of sexism, I allege that he's crossed the line into post-rationalist neo-Hegelianism. He wants to produce an army of mindless insects who will obey his every command. To produce such an army, Michael plans to destroy people's minds using either drugs or an advanced form of lobotomy. Whichever approach he takes, before he initiated a nihilism flap to help promote his cranky utterances, people everywhere were expected to strengthen our roots so we can weather the storms that threaten our foundation. Nowadays, it's the rare person indeed who realizes that his dupes remain largely silent when asked about the correlative connecting him to egoism. The rare times they do deign to comment they invariably skew the issue to prevent people from realizing that Michael's ballyhoos cannot stand on their own merit. That's why they're dependent on elaborate artifices and explanatory stories to convince us that Michael's blessing is the equivalent of a papal imprimatur. Michael's working towards the day when he (and only he) can dictate what you may say, whom you may know, where you may live, and how you may behave. And that's all I have to say.

A little curious fact on originals and copies (in the case of architecture, not humans): Japan has a shrine called Ise Jingu, that is being rebuilt every twenty years. It's copied from the original standing on spot A onto spot B. After the work is complete, the original shrine is demounted. After twenty years, the spot B shrine becomes the original that is copied onto spot A. Since this has been going on for roughly 1400 years, today's shrine is a copy of a copy of a copy of a copy (x 70) of an abstract original that existed a long time ago. Now simulacra this :]

@Vsauce Awesome stuff. But here are here are some interesting counter perspective because your point is a bit nihilistic to my taste. True, we are instances of life, a mere information than material, insignificant pieces of the universe experiences itself and assembles matter in an encoded genetic program. But, due to genetic variation, as a species, our own identity remains in our signature trait. None of your ancestors can do what you or I can do. Having genotypic variation is like having a monogrammed iPhone, you know others have the same device as you do but yours is different and unique, and this paves way to our notable faces, behaviors, life expectancies and the like. So, in a way, we all are sub-species in our own. So, how about identical twins? Don't they share genetic material? Definitely, but our own self awareness lies in our own neural network and we're talking about combination of on average 100 billion cells. Among the limitless permutation, only one gives rise to you or anyone else, at least in their current state. Our memories are different which will define us eventually even if we do look alike. Therefore, I find your conclusion to be contradictory to your generalization of forgery. In the grand scheme of things, we all are star dust and a primordial coacervate of mytotic prokaryote, but we are self-acclaimed beings, nonetheless, in the universe we know because of imperfect forgery.
If you think about it, there is a combination of 1s and 0s that would make up a picture of you motorboating Kate Upton without this event actually happening.

This is a paradox that relates to this video (kinda), if you had a boat made out of 1000 pieces of wood. Every once and a while you replaced an old piece with a new piece. The question is, overtime when all pieces have been replaced, if you assemble a boat with the exact design as your current one with your old pieces, which ship is the original?

You say the fact that we have 99.9% the same DNA as a talking point for the idea that everyone is very similar to each other, and should think of each other as family on an emotional level.  

Humans share 50% DNA with bananas, and we also share 98.8% DNA with chimps, there are pretty big differences in those cases.  That single percentage seems to change a lot.  Also, from what I read, lot of our DNA accomplishes nothing at all, we weren't programmed very efficiently.  

My point is, you should not be using peoples intuitive understanding of percentages to mislead them this way.

Anyway, if it's all family squabbles, then are we having incest all the time? I understand it's interesting and theoretical, but everything has a limit. We can't go on for ever. Or can't we? Our understanding is limited, we agree that the universe is limited, although there might be unlimited number of them, the speed of light is the limit and even time has a limit, but does existence cease to exist after that? If our understanding is right, do all universes just pop out of existence and there is nothing? I mean, we came out of conceivably nothing, but if it end it all had to start somewhere, be it a multi-verse. Then maybe there are actually no limits? Just maybe existence in itself in a form that is unknown to us, different from our current existence and possible understanding limited by that existence? No matter how skeptical of the limit of the speed of light I may be, I couldn't accept something coming from nothing. Just like axioms in mathematics the world must have an axiom of existence then. Even the theorized big bang started from a concentration of energy and E=MC^2 (though that's simplified and not really correct). But as humans living in this world in this universe in this existence, we are limited, because we as part of existence can't escape it all, we can never truly understand how it all works. We would have to be outside this world, beyond nature. In simplified, more known terms, we would have to be GODS, those who control the existence itself, to be able to understand it all. And let's be honest, that too much of a fiction.
Unless we are a simulation run by some intelligent existence and so we have the beginning of the simulation But then they would need a start too.
The world is truly amazing,

no dna replication isn't "forgery" it's not meant to decisive. Just to replicate. And as it's just the instructions to make the cell it's replacing. Not all the D.N.A. chain is activated when just making say a brain cell. Then the cell splits it has to recombine the dna strand. Making a wholly new structure based on the old. If anything it's using the original to make new originals. But there is no way to have a full replication of the cell as that cell would have to split again just as the old cell was doing. i.e. cancer. and we all know how good them cells are doing their jobs. We'd never grow or change. Witch is the point isn't it? It's only from the view of conserving structure that you could see replication as forgery. But remember we're the subjects, the dna is the blue print. And in the end the dna does it's job and makes us, and changes us. Like as if you gave us the instructions for making "mona lisa" and we put all the parts together right, you'd have the mona lisa, but not as made by da vinci. Now although we made the same thing the value was placed on the artiest not the art. The forgery isn't that the object wasn't made right, but wasn't made by the right person. The reducibility of our body to elementary functions and forms does not necessarily have to reduce us to forgeries. There is another possibility, which is that there is something to be forged that is precisely the opposite of a copy. As hinted at in the video, each experienced moment is a kind of unrepeatable performance. Instead of focusing on the absence of a concrete physical object, we can look at the aesthetic content of the experience itself as the concrete phenomenon - not a simulacrum (pronounced sim-you-lah-crum) but a localized fragment of authenticity itself. Is color basically a bad copy of white light? Is the universe basically a bad copy of nothingness?

Humans are not bad copies of anything, but the degree to which we are unique snowflakes is relative to the proximity of our scope of consideration. Within our own frame of reference, we are absolutely unique. Within a social frame of reference, we are stereotyped culturally. Moving out from the human context, an individual human becomes more and more generic - a mammal, an animal, a biological organism, a chemical reaction, etc. This variance is, in my view, what the universe is ‘made of’, so that no one context of description is the final ‘real’ description.

In other words, this conversation is "here", and that video is "there", and that is what relativity ultimately means...perception itself - awareness*, is the ultimate frame of reference, and without perception, there is nothing to frame.

*Not human awareness...that would be solipsism. What I'm talking about is what I call Multisense Realism.

Why is where important? Your videos have an aura about them as well--they evoke the same emotive response as your example of a sweater dropped in dog poo, or allegedly worn by a mass-murderer--perhaps to a lesser degree in most people, but that it happens at all is remarkable, and should tell us something important about the period we live in.

Originals are only important because we perceive that they are important. This can be seen with interactions with digital media--unfortunately especially digital media which makes us angry like trolling. Digital media is going to become a larger and larger part of our lives as we move forward, and we will, as a species develop stronger emotive relationships with digital things and probably begin to lose some of the emotive relationships we have with parts of the physical world. As we undergo the growth pains associated with the transition into the digital media age, the question of originality is going to become less meaningful as the lines between originals and copies continue to become more and more blurred (hopefully not in relation to plagiarism, but in relation to emotive connections with works of art and other categories of ideas). Some day, perhaps people will actually be able to take a virtual tour through the Louvre which possesses exactly the same ambiance as visiting the museum in person. If the simulation is sufficiently advanced, interactive and detailed, it need not hold real distinction from physicality within the perception of those experiencing it.

I think we need to readdress what is "worth" when storing things. We like to store original copies of paintings for the museums but for the sake of space, time and money, it is cheaper to have a copy and show people it. People seemed to think it is more important to have the original but I believe that the act of just appreciating something even though it's a copy, is just as much worth when it comes to learning about it. A copy makes something more accessible to everything so we don't have to travel to a far off place to see it. I can go to France to see the Mona Lisa but I can still appreciate a copy of it I buy at a gift shop at the Art Institute.

You think you know who you are because it is all you can remember, but those memories only exist at this moment. Did your beloved goldfish starve to death? This reminds me of the "Star Trek transporter dilemma" in some ways. The idea is that your original self is "killed" by having their atoms disassembled and a "duplicate" is created when they're reassembled. However, if the process reassembles your atoms in EXACTLY the same configuration they were in originally, that "duplicate" is technically more YOU than you yourself will be several years later-at least by the logic of a person being defined as a specific combination of atoms arranged in a specific manner.

I don't know about your answer to the original video question. It all depends how we define "video". As a computer scientist, when I talk about a program, I mean the set of instructions that describe how that program is to execute. Likewise, I would say a video is the set of instructions that describe light and sounds, and where and when they go. So the original video is the first set of instructions that replicate this particular sequence of light and sound--on your hard drive.


If we instead define the video as the light and sound sequence itself, then the original video doesn't exist, since this edited form never really happened except as computer code.

Its a little amazing that he didn't mention Walter Benjamin, with his "Art in the age of mechanical reproduction". Although it addresses the same idea, art has an aura. The further you move away from that "original", the fainter and fainter it becomes. 
The reproducibility give you a little bit of that aura, like me having a Mona Lisa fridge magnet. And a fridge magnet from the 2004 US election of Edvard Munch's scream, with the caption "BUSH AGAIN!!!" 
I feel so cultured...

But, I think with art forms unlike painting, or theatre. Where there is one originator, or one performance (with other performances, there will be small changes). In things like bronze sculpture, or photography. The original means very little, as these pieces are created from one negative, or one cast. And you don't go to an art museum to look at a cast, or negative.
So, that sort of raises the question that Sherry Levine raises, with her appropriation of Walker Evans. Is the print, the negative. or maybe the physical subject matter. Which is the original? Nothing is original in art after all...

Okay, we share 99.9 % of or DNA yes, but all those genes are expressed differently between people so there actually is quite a bit of variation between individuals of ANY species.  Saying we are billion year old replicas only changed by mutation isn't accurate at all, we are more like the pigments in the Mona Lisa melted down and reapplied to make a new portrait than we are like forgeries of our parents.

His comment on value around 3:00 leads to a very interesting topic about value. It's weird because value is subjective; and therefore, if you can convince someone something is valuable, then by definition it is now valuable (to them at least). This leads to a whole field of study with elements like marketing and manipulating the media to provide things like manufactured celebrities; once you convince someone that a person is popular; they now are popular to that person (ei important; like a noteworthy artist whose fame brings value by association). The Kardashians are a good example of this I feel. Now that they have been established and are in the public's eye, they are a platform for advertisement that can be monetized. A lot can be said here and it's very interesting.

I disagree with what you said about the original raw data not being the original "video." Yes, they are instructions to make the video viewable to us, but it doesn't mean that the data isn't actually the video.
It is a representation of the video. It's a medium. The data on the hard drive is a medium for a video in the same way that paint on a canvas is the medium for the Mona Lisa, so to say that the first copy of the data isn't "the original" video is almost to say that the Mona Lisa isn't "the original" image, but rather a way of displaying the original image that appeared in Leonardo Davinci's mind.
It's an interesting thought, but I disagree. The first copy of the data is the original video, but just not a video in the same way we think of what a video is.

It's bad enough to think I'm related to every living thing on the planet but how in the hell can we be related to inanimate objects which were never alive to begin with? Rocks are not living creatures, there are living creatures that look like rocks but they are not actually rocks. Real rocks do not grow, they don't reproduce, they don't think, they don't breath, they don't have any of the scientific traits that define what life is. And family, biologically speaking, is just defined by reproduction. You are family with anyone who comes from the same reproductive gene pool. So you can not possibly be related to something that isn't even capable of reproduction. Now family can go beyond just the biological definition, like being related to someone who is married to a biological relative or adopting a child. Biologically it doesn't make any difference but legally you are still related. Then there's another thing where despite the fact that science and the law does not recognize you as a family, you still feel close enough to that person or people to consider them family. That last one seems more real than the idea of being related to a rock.
